channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: China Sentences Brother-in-Law of Nobel Laureate to Prison
item.description: The sentence is being widely seen as political persecution of the Nobel laureate Liu Xiaobo, who is himself serving an 11-year prison sentence.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: North and South Korean Officials Meet to Arrange Talks
item.description: Delegations met in the border village of Panmumjom to set conditions for the first cabinet minister-level discussion in six years.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Tom Sharpe, Darkly Satirical British Novelist, Dies at 85
item.description: Mr. Sharpe, whose books included “Porterhouse Blue” and the Henry Wilt series, used crudity and excess in taking on targets like racism, the aristocracy and academia.
item.dc:creator: By MARGALIT FOX
item.media:description: Tom Sharpe in 2009; his books, which were best sellers in Britain, included “Porterhouse Blue” and the Henry Wilt series.

item.title: Trial Sends Warning to Rank-and-File Putin Foes
item.description: Russia’s prosecution of low-level participants at protests seems to be a message to other ordinary Russians about taking part.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: Defendants accused in a protest against the government waited Thursday for a hearing in Moscow. The chance of acquittal is slim.

item.title: Revelations Give Look at Spy Agency’s Wider Reach
item.description: A revolution in software technology has transformed the National Security Agency by providing automated and instantaneous analysis of volumes of digital information.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By JAMES RISEN and ERIC LICHTBLAU
item.media:description: At the National Security Agency in Fort Meade, Md. Disclosures have provided a rare glimpse into the agency’s growing reach.

item.title: Militia Members Fire On Demonstrators in Benghazi
item.description: Members of a powerful militia fired on protesters surrounding the group’s headquarters on the edge of Benghazi in an outpouring of public anger.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SULIMAN ALI ZWAY and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Britain Told to Hand Over War Prisoners
item.description: President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan demanded the transfer of up to 90 Afghan detainees being held at a British base, saying the detention violates Afghan law.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: U.S. and China Pledge New Model of Cooperation
item.description: President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China ended two days of informal meetings, moving closer on pressuring a nuclear North Korea, but remaining divided over cyberespionage.
item.dc:creator: By JACKIE CALMES and STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China and President Obama took a walk Saturday on the grounds of the Sunnylands estate in California.

item.title: White House Plays Down Data Program
item.description: The Obama administration defended its collection of private Internet and telephone data, arguing that a secret program called Prism is simply an “internal government computer system.”
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN WEISMAN and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:credit: From left, Susan Walsh/AP; Charles Dharapak/AP; Susan Walsh/AP; Larry Downing/Reuters
item.media:description: From left, Assistant Attorney General Ronald Weich and Senators Ron Wyden, Mark Udall and Richard J. Durbin. Mr. Wyden and Mr. Udall have criticized techniques that Mr. Weich defends.

item.title: 3 Americans and Italian Soldier Killed in Afghanistan
item.description: In one attack, an Afghan soldier opened fire on international troops serving with him in eastern Afghanistan, officials said, killing two American soldiers and a civilian. In the second attack, an Italian soldier was killed when a grenade was thrown at him.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Rape and Murder Stirs Fury in South Africa
item.description: Before she died, the victim provided the name of the man who assaulted her, but the case against him was nonetheless dismissed for lack of evidence.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN
item.media:credit: Per-Anders Pettersson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jonathan Davids was charged with raping and killing Anene Booysen, who accused him before dying, but then prosecutors said they lacked evidence.

item.title: Attacker in Afghanistan Hid Bomb in His Body
item.description: A suicide attacker seeking an audience with Afghanistan’s spy chief, Asadullah Khalid, used a body-cavity bomb after being strip searched.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Emirates Balk at Activism in Region Hit by Uprisings
item.description: As part of a broader trend in the region, the United Arab Emirates has moved aggressively to shut down a group that sought political change and a more Islamic government.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: In the Emirates, Dubai contrasts with the more conservative Ras al Khaymah.

item.title: News Analysis: A Golden Age for Intervention?
item.description: Don’t expect Samantha Power and Susan Rice to lead a new humanitarian crusade.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: President Obama with National Security Adviser Tom Donilon; Susan E. Rice, center, named to be his successor; and Samantha Power, right, nominated to succeed Ms. Rice as U.N. ambassador.

item.title: Editorial: Immigration Reform Headwinds in the Senate
item.description: As the Senate debates immigration reform, count on Republicans to try to make it fail.
item.dc:creator: By THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Peeping President Obama
item.description: A lot of American values are being sacrificed on the altar of American security.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By MAUREEN DOWD
item.media:credit: Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Your Smartphone Is Watching You
item.description: You can have privacy or you can have the Internet, but you can’t have both.
item.dc:creator: By ROSS DOUTHAT
item.media:description: For many Americans, the upside of government watchfulness is worth the trade-off.

item.title: Remembering Two Seminal Kennedy Speeches
item.description: Two of the finest presidential speeches of the 20th century, by John F. Kennedy, on the Soviet Union and civil rights, also had immediate results.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM CLYMER
item.media:description: "We are confronted primarily with a moral issue. It is as old as the Scriptures and is as clear as the American Constitution," said President John F. Kennedy on June 11, 1963, taking up the issue of civil rights.

item.title: U.S. Helps Allies Trying to Battle Iranian Hackers
item.description: The administration has begun helping Middle Eastern allies build their defenses against Iran’s cyberweapons and will do the same in Asia to contain attacks from North Korea.
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Chinese Link Bus Blast That Killed 47 to Jobless Man’s Suicide
item.description: Reports about the explosion aboard a bus in the southeastern city of Xiamen identified the man as Chen Shuizong, who was about 60 and unemployed.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Syria Opposition Won’t Attend Talks Unless Rebels Get Arms, Commander Says
item.description: The proposal to hold talks in Geneva at a point when the Syrian opposition has suffered a bitter reversal has led many in the opposition to question the West’s strategy.
item.category: National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: City’s Newest Immigrant Enclaves, From Little Guyana to Meokjagolmok
item.description: Sri Lankans have gathered on Staten Island, Arabs in Brooklyn, Ghanaians in the Bronx: A guide to the new immigrant enclaves.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left, an Arab neighborhood in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn; a Sri Lankan New Year’s celebration on Staten Island; a Mexican area of Sunset Park, Brooklyn; Ghanaians in the Bronx, where their large immigrant group is centered.

item.title: DealBook: France Expands Inquiry Into Tax Evasion at UBS
item.description: UBS, the target of a widening tax-evasion case in France, was placed under formal investigation on suspicion that it illegally helped French citizens to set up secret accounts abroad.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY
item.media:description: The Swiss bank UBS in Zurich.

item.title: India Ink: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
item.description: A round-up of news from across India.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Nelson Mandela Hospitalized Again for Lung Infection
item.description: The former South African leader Nelson Mandela was in “serious but stable condition,” the government said.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN
item.media:description: Nelson Mandela, the former South African president, in 2012.
